content.text: The Ugly Duckling’s Friend  Once upon a time, in a quiet corner of a sunlit farmyard, there lived a mother duck who was very proud of her six little ducklings.
Five of them were fluffy and yellow, with bright eyes and cheerful quacks.
But the sixth duckling was different—large, gray, and awkward, with feathers that stuck out in all the wrong directions.
The other ducklings giggled and whispered, "Look at him!
He’s so ugly!" And though the mother duck loved all her children, even she couldn’t help but sigh when she looked at him.
One day, the ugly duckling waddled away from the farmyard, his heart heavy with sadness.
"No one wants me," he thought.
"I don’t belong here." He wandered through the tall grass, past the pond where the frogs croaked, and into the deep woods where the trees whispered secrets.
The wind rustled the leaves, and the stars twinkled above, but the duckling felt more alone than ever.
Just as he was about to give up hope, he heard a soft voice.
"Why do you look so sad?"  The duckling turned to see a small, scruffy hedgehog sitting on a mossy rock.
His spines were tangled with twigs, and his nose was dusted with pollen, but his eyes were kind.
"I—I don’t know where I belong," the duckling admitted.
"The other ducks say I’m ugly, and I don’t look like them at all."  The hedgehog tilted his head.
"Hmm. Well, I don’t look like the other hedgehogs either.
My spines are too short, and I’m terrible at curling into a ball. But you know what?
That doesn’t mean we can’t be friends."  The duckling blinked.
"You… you want to be my friend?"  "Of course!" said the hedgehog, grinning.
"Friends don’t have to look the same.
They just have to care about each other."  And so, the two unlikely friends spent the day together.
The hedgehog showed the duckling how to find the juiciest berries, and the duckling taught the hedgehog how to float on the pond (though the hedgehog did sink a little).
They laughed as fireflies danced around them, and when the moon rose high, they curled up together under a blanket of leaves.
Days turned into weeks, and the duckling’s heart grew lighter.
He still didn’t look like the other ducks, but he didn’t mind as much anymore.
He had a friend who liked him just the way he was.
One morning, as the first golden light touched the pond, the duckling stretched his wings—and gasped.
They were no longer gray and clumsy. They were strong, white, and shimmering like snow.
He flapped them once, twice, and suddenly, he was soaring above the trees!
The hedgehog cheered from below as the duckling circled the sky, his heart filled with joy.
"You’re not an ugly duckling anymore!" the hedgehog called. "You’re a swan!"  The swan landed gracefully beside his friend.
"And you’re the best friend I could ever ask for," he said.
From that day on, the swan and the hedgehog were inseparable.
The swan would glide across the pond while the hedgehog watched from the shore, and when winter came, they snuggled together in a cozy burrow.
The other animals in the farmyard whispered about how strange it was—a swan and a hedgehog being friends.
But the swan and the hedgehog didn’t care.
They knew that true friendship didn’t depend on how you looked, but on how you made each other feel.
And so, under the watchful eyes of the moon and stars, they lived happily ever after.
